awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Towards an Accurate, High-Fidelity Modeling System for Multiphysics and Multiscale Coastal Ocean Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
In correspondence with global warming and fast expansion of human activities in coastal waters, it is now becoming urgently needed to advance our modeling capabilities to a level of direct, high-fidelity simulation of many emerging, real-world, multiphysics, multiscale coastal ocean flow problems. Examples of these problems include oil spill at bottom of oceans, tidal energy extraction in coastal waters, etc. Currently, essentially there is no model at this level of simulation. The objective of this project is to develop computational methods and an unprecedented computer modeling system, which will be not only applicable to such problems but also a new platform to study many other problems.

In particular, a geophysical fluid dynamics model and a fully 3D fluid dynamics model are integrated via domain decomposition and two-way coupling into a single modeling system, in which the former captures mesoscale [O(10) km - O(10,000) km], background ocean currents and the latter resolves sub-mesoscale [O(1) m - O(10) km], complicated, local phenomena. The objective will be realized via three tasks: 1) Methods and algorithms with regard to solution accuracy, computational efficiency, and transmission condition. 2) Numerical experiments on the methods and algorithms, their validation in test problems, and a showcase application. 3) Development of a robust, efficient software package of the modeling system. The educational component aims at increasing awareness of students, especially those from underrepresented groups, on new computational problems and necessity for new methods of their solution, stimulating their interest in numerical algorithms and model development. The activities of this component include a series of seminars, teaching material development, etc.

por.por_cntn:
The project has made several new findings and developed several new computational methods
for solving fluid dynamics such as river and ocean flows, gas dynamics, shock waves,
and wave problems such as electromagnetic waves and acoustic waves.

Intellectual Merit

The Back and Forth Error Compensation and Correction method (BFECC) was originally developed by
the PI and his collaborator for solving the convection of flows more accurately. It has been
further developed in this project as a general purpose method to improve the interpolation
accuracy on irregular meshes conveniently. BFECC method basically calls any linear
interpolation subroutine 3 times to make it a more accurate local 3rd order interpolation
method. The PI and his collaborators have successfully developed this method for the
interface interpolation between two ocean flow models which can handle smoothly varying
irregular grids. They also developed a strategy for it to interpolate between meshes of
different sizes and find a case when it can't achieve its theoretical order of accuracy
(but still reduces the error) which provides useful guidance in applications.
 
The PI and his student have further improved the previously developed BFECC limiter into a
conservative version so that it can be used on conservation laws and kinetic equations.
Preliminary results on 1D Burgers' equation is very good. Application on multi dimensional
conservation laws on unstructured meshes will explored. They also apply BFECC to solving
Maxwell's equations and have achieved major success ! This new finite difference method is
simple to code, 2nd order accurate, doesn't use a staggered grid, and can be easily formulated
on irregular meshes. This opens up a new window toward efficient finite difference methods on
irregular meshes for electromagnetic waves and other wave problems (conventional finite
difference methods despite their efficiency are hard to use on irregular meshes.) Several
new developments based on it are being initiated.

The PI and his colleagues have developed new methods for finding underlying partial differential
equations given experimental data. An evolution based technique has been introduced to effectively
eliminate redundant (wrong) terms in the equation, and noise reduction techniques have been
developed so that the methods can handle a significant amount of noise in the data.

The PI and his collaborators have extended the constant-subtraction technique (proposed by the PI
and his collaborators earlier) for shallow water equations to discontinuous Galerkin methods on
triangular meshes, and verified that the remainder modification for the Hierarchical Reconstruction
limiting won't hurt the order of accuracy in these meshes if the solution is smooth.

Broader Impacts

The BFECC interpolation method shows significant improvement on the accuracy near the interface area
in 3D multi-component fluid simulations. Since the procedure doesn't mind the choice of underlying
low order methods, some very simple methods can be used which will make the numerical method on even
3D non uniform meshes very simple and easy to implement, and will be able to extend to higher
dimensions in which the reduction of complexity and implementation difficulty will be more and more
significant. Because interpolation methods are widely used in scientific and engineering computation,
the impact from this new method could be large.

The new BFECC-based finite difference methods for solving electromagnetic waves
are so convenient for irregular meshes that scientist and engineers can easily adapt them to
various scattering problems and be able to focus on the physical conditions on the interface. It could
also be very efficient for solving acoustic waves on complicated media and geometry with applications
in biomedical ultrasound and metamaterials. The application of the new method is related to antenna
design, metal detection, cloaking devices, aircrafts, cellular devices, ultrasonic detection and
treatment devices etc.

The methods for finding underlying partial differential equations given experimental data are useful in
data mining for scientific and engineering experiments and medical treatments.

This work for shallow water equations paves the way to real applications because it can conveniently
convert a well regarded general-purpose method to one efficient for shallow water problems involving
complicated geometry and mesh, such as river flows, lakes, ocean flows etc.
